channel.title: Destrution of life
channel.description: well my m8 was telling me if ww3 ever happend there would be noone left right? beacause like it would be a big nucular fight... one country would nuke the other then they would nuke back then there allias would nuke you then your allias would nuke them... so would ww3 be the destruction of life?

item.title: Destrution of life
item.dc:creator: @Gotta_Catch_Them_All Gotta Catch Them All
item.description:
@Gotta_Catch_Them_All wrote:

[quote=“The Prince of Randomness, post:24, topic:68101”][quote author=xxlegitxx link=topic=99652.msg1017465#msg1017465 date=1174018757]

yes i think he does, in 195?, the amreicans droped the atom bomb on the japan/china, place…

First off, it was 1945. And it was two bombs, in Nagasaki and Hiroshima, JAPAN.

and they iver died or got mutated… i think it helped unpopulate the world

You, sir, are a retard. I think this dumbass deserves a ban for sheer stupidity.

No one ‘got mutated.’ Maybe some cancer, but no Magneto’s running around. It did not ‘help unpopulate the world.’ Tbh, it was a drop in the bucket. 200,000 people died. That’s it. That’s less than 0.1% of the US’s current population and less than 0.008% of the world population at the time.
[/quote]

cancer = mutation i think.[/quote]

Cancer = Cancer…

Read full topic

item.title: Destrution of life
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

goatee:

Lmao atom bomb. Thats so old… a nuclear bomb would cause much more destruction.

Mopman:

An atom bomb is a type of nuclear bomb…

Mopman:

True, but “Atom bomb” isn’t entirely synonymous with “Nuclear bomb”. Atom bomb usually refers to fission based weapons, and then you’d got fusion based weapons such as Hydrogen bombs. Both are “Nuclear Bombs”.

They are the same thing. Since “atomic bomb” was used in the 1940s it tends to be associated with the earliest pure fission weapons (of course, this is just from an American perspective - e.g. 30s-40s German physicists tended to use the term “uranium bomb”). The bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945 are generally called atomic bombs.

I assume that the use of “nuclear bomb” now is either a slightly more accurate name or a misused abbreviation of “thermonuclear”. Thermonuclear refers strictly to the fusion weapons that make up most modern arsenals. Even then it’s not entirely accurate, since as far as I know all fusion weapons are initiated by a smaller fission explosion (it’s called staged radiation implosion, invented in the early 1950s).

Ok, enough lecture (nuclear weapons are interesting), if you’re interested here’s a great site.

The question was whether or not we could destroy all life on the planet with a nuclear war. The answer is "probably"

We could irradiate the entire surface of the planet, no doubt about it. Detonate several large salted bombs (designed for extra fallout) high enough in the atmosphere and air currents would spread the debris very, very far away from the detonation site.

The US and various states of the former USSR possess more than enough weapons to accomplish this. The fact that most of the active ones are aimed at centers of population, utilities, and infrastructure means that most humans would likely die in the initial blasts. If that were followed up with the salted bombs I mentioned earlier, probably all higher mammals and most reptiles would die soon after.

There might be survivors (anyone far enough underground, naturally resistant animals, etc). If they managed to find food and avoid lethal doses of radiation, a species might eventually evolve that isn’t killed by radiation. Maybe. And it would take a very long time.

PS - The quote from Einstein is “I know not with what weapons World War III will be fought, but World War IV will be fought with sticks and stones.”

Read full topic

True, but “Atom bomb” isn’t entirely synonymous with “Nuclear bomb”. Atom bomb usually refers to fission based weapons, and then you’d got fusion based weapons such as Hydrogen bombs. Both are “Nuclear Bombs”.

I think I got that the right way round, anyway. Fusion being more powerful than Fission?
